Just a thought (came back to post it so I hope it was off of this video I thought the comment came from), the reason Mars missions go off of polar orbit might be to avoid the van allen belts the way the Apollo missions did. a couple of google searches seems to indicate that geostationary orbit is actually inside of the upper van allen belt so for unmanned missions to mars it shouldn't have been that much of an issue I would assume.

PLEASE - PLEASE - PLEASE
Tim, we love your videos! Your enthusiasm for rocketry is contagious, and the Kerbal videos are educational.
HOWEVER, for us newbies, we don't understand some of the basics of Kerbal,. You whiz through a lot of the controls & astro-mechanics (post-launch) so fast, it's hard to keep up.
Could you PLEASE make a "Kerbal Primer" for us, explaining (among other things) how you launch, stop/start engines, select trajectories (with that spinney globe thingy), where the numbers are for acceleration/Delta-V/Apoapsis/Periapsis/suicide-burn [ and what they mean - and how you use them to set trajectories ], how you separate stages, and what stats you use to decide how to do a landing burn. Basically, take us through from launch-to-landing 'splaining everything you do & why.
Thanks - I'm sure us rookies would enjoy the videos even more, without question marks popping up in our brains every time you do something and why you chose to execute those commands at the moment you did.

Modlist Please :)

have a look at these minimum specs for the kerbal space program
2.0Ghz Dual Core CPU or higher (preferably higher)
* 4GB RAM
* 512MB Video Card, Shader Model 3.0
* 4GB Free HD space
* Windows Vista, 7, 8 or 10
* An Intel-based Mac running Mac OS X 10.8 or higher
* A Debian based Linux distro

suggest
4ghz quad core
8gb ram
2gb video
8gb HDD with 1gb SSD for cache

that will run the prog smooth or better
Can't you assign max throttle levels to an action group?

BFR all the way. Far more innovative than SLS & unlike SLS SpaceX has actual plans for BFR that includes colonizing Mars on a big scale with the possibility of lunar colonization as well. SLS was started on a pipe dream (NASA's Journey to Mars) & in the aftermath of the cancellation of Constellation program with funding setbacks & the only thing that kept SLS relevant all these years was job creation after the Shuttle retirement. To me SLS is just a government boondoggle using old 20th century tech taken from the Shuttle era & it is sucking funding from necessary programs within NASA like commercial crew which has been delayed because of lack of funding. Also a real turn off for SLS is the fact that such an expensive rocket is expendable. That's $500 million up to $1 billion thrown away after every mission & it will only launch once every two to three years.
